facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated August 3, 1960, of the Bombay High Court in Cr. A. No. 282 of 1960.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated August 3, 1960, of the Bombay High, Court in Cr. A. No. 282 of 1960. S. R. Chari, M. K. Ramamurthi, R. K. Garg, D. P. Singh, C. Aggarwal, L. M. Atmaram Bhukhanwala and K. R. Choudhri, for the appellant.

facts.text: The judgment of the Court was delivered by MUDHOLKAR, J. on September 28, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: 1962. September 28. The judgment of the Court was delivered by MUDHOLKAR, J.-In this appeal by special leave from the judgment of the High Court of Bombay affirming the conviction and sentences passed on the appellant in respect of offences under s. 161, Indian Penal Code and s. 5(1)(d) of the Prevention of Corruption Act, 1947 (2 of 1947) read with s. 5(2) thereof,

facts.text: High Court of Bombay affirmed the conviction and sentences passed on the appellant for offences under s. 161 IPC and s. 5(1)(d) of Prevention of Corruption Act read with s. 5(2).

anchor.surface_text: In this appeal by special leave from the judgment of the High Court of Bombay affirming the conviction and sentences passed on the appellant in respect of offences under s. 161, Indian Penal Code and s. 5 1  d  of the Prevention of Corruption Act, 1947  2 of 1947  read with s. 5 2  thereof,

facts.text: Appellant appointed Resident Engineer for Light Houses in 1954 and posted to Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: In the year 1954 the appellant was appointed Resident Engineer for Light Houses and posted to Bombay. He was due to retire in January, 1955 but he was given extensions from time to time.

facts.text: Appellant due to retire in January 1955 but given extensions from time to time.

anchor.surface_text: He was due to retire in January, 1955 but he was given extensions from time to time. The complainant, M. M. Patel  who will hereafter be referred to as the complainant  is a building contractor.

facts.text: Complainant M.M. Patel is a building contractor.

anchor.surface_text: The complainant, M. M. Patel  who will hereafter be referred to as the complainant  is a building contractor. It was proposed to reconstruct a light house at Tolkeshwar Point which is situated on the West Coast, somewhere between Ratnagiri and Karwar The complainant submitted a tender for the construction on March 21, 1956.

facts.text: Complainant submitted tender for reconstruction of lighthouse at Tolkeshwar Point on March 21, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: It was proposed to reconstruct a light house at Tolkeshwar Point which is situated on the West Coast, somewhere between Ratnagiri and Karwar The complainant submitted a tender for the construction on March 21, 1956. That tender was accepted on June 30, 1956 and a work order was issued to him.

facts.text: Tender accepted on June 30, 1956 and work order issued to complainant.

anchor.surface_text: That tender was accepted on June 30, 1956 and a work order was issued to him. The general conditions governing the contract. are contained in the set of papers inviting tenders. The complainant commenced the work in November, 1956.

facts.text: Complainant commenced work in November 1956.

anchor.surface_text: The complainant commenced the work in November, 1956. It would appear that the overseer supervising the work was not satisfied with the manner in which the contractor was carrying on the work.

facts.text: In December 1956, appellant warned complainant to carry out work according to specifications.

anchor.surface_text: As a result, in December, 1956, the appellant had to bring the fact to the complainants notice and warn him to carry out the work according to the specification contained in the notice inviting tenders.

facts.text: Well near dharmashala attached to Tolkeshwar temple was only convenient water source, water up to 6 feet depth at relevant time.

anchor.surface_text: There is also a well near the dharmashala, and that well is the only convenient source of water supply to the neighbourhood. At the relevant time the water in it was upto a depth of six feet.

facts.text: It is admitted that the well has not been deepened.

anchor.surface_text: But it is an admitted fact that the well has not been deepened. It is also admitted that the contractor used the well water for carrying on his work without obtaining any express permission of the trustees and by the time he finished the work the water level had gone down to a little below two feet.

facts.text: Contractor used well water without permission, water level went down to below two feet by end of work.

anchor.surface_text: It is also admitted that the contractor used the well water for carrying on his work without obtaining any express permission of the trustees and by the time he finished the work the water level had gone down to a little below two feet.

facts.text: Both courts found appellant did not visit Tolkeshwar in February 1957, but High Court held demand for bribe made in June 1957.

anchor.surface_text: According to the complainant in February, 1957, the appellant had paid a visit to Tolkeshwar and during his visit he told the complainant to behave like other contractors evidently suggesting that he should also pay him certain percentage of his bills as a bribe. It is sufficient to say that both the courts have found that the appellant did not visit Tolkeshwar in February, 1957, but the High Court has held that the appellant did make a demand for bribe in June, 1957,

facts.text: On March 26, 1957 one Bhatia posted as Overseer.

anchor.surface_text: On March 26, 1957 one Bhatia was posted as Overseer there and though on March 30, 1957. a cheque for Rs. 7,278 odd was given to the complainant on his first running bill.

facts.text: Cheque for Rs. 7,278 given to complainant on first running bill on March 30, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: and though on March 30, 1957. a cheque for Rs. 7,278 odd was given to the complainant on his first running bill. Bhatia made a complaint to the appellant on April 2, 1957, that the complainant was not carrying on his work satisfactorily and was not affording facilities to him for supervising the work.

facts.text: Appellant received Rs. 1,000 in currency notes from complainant on April 6, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: On April 6, 1959, the complainant. went to the office of the appellant and saw him in his cabin. There the cheque was handed over by the appellant to the complainant. But before that., according to the complainant, he paid Rs. 1,000 in currency notes to the appellant.

facts.text: Police recovered Rs. 1,000 currency notes besmeared with anthracene powder from appellant's pocket on April 6, 1959; traces on pockets and fingers of both.

anchor.surface_text: Having done that he came out and then certain police officials accompanied by panchas entered the room. On being required to produce the money by the police officials the appellant promptly took out the currency notes from his pocket. It may be mentioned that the currency notes were besmeared with anthracene powder and it is common ground that traces of anthracene powder were found not only on the pocket of the appellant but also on his fingers and those of the complainant.

facts.text: Receipt of Rs. 1,000 by appellant admitted, not legal remuneration.

anchor.surface_text: Thus the receipt of Rs. 1,000/- was admitted by the appellant. This was admittedly not the appellants legal remuneration.

facts.text: Cheque for ninth running bill Rs. 22,000 odd prepared on March 23, 1959 but not handed over to complainant on that date. Admitted fact.

anchor.surface_text: It is an admitted4 fact that though the cheque for payment of Rs. 22,000 odd for the ninth running bill was prepared on March 23, 1959, it was not handed over to the complainant on that date.

facts.text: Special Judge passed sentence of one year imprisonment on appellant.

anchor.surface_text: A plea was made before us that in view of the age of the appellant and the fact that he was just about to retire when the prosecution was started we should reduce the sentence to the period already undergone. These circumstances were borne in mind by the learned Special judge when he passed a substantive sentence of imprisonment of one year only though the maximum for the offence is seven years.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal.

anchor.surface_text: In the circumstances we dismiss the appeal.

facts.text: High Court rejected appellant's explanation that Rs.1000 was for temple authorities.

anchor.surface_text: It is because of these circumstances and because it believed the statement of the complainant that the appellant had asked him for a bribe that the High Court did not accept the appellants explanation that the money was paid by the complainant to him for being passed on to the temple trustee as true.

arguments.claim: The presumption raised against the appellant under s. 4 of the Prevention of Corruption Act must be held to have been rebutted by the explanation given by him inasmuch as that explanation was both reasonable and probable

anchor.surface_text: the only point urged is that the presumption raised against the appellant under s. 4 of the Prevention of Corruption Act must be held to have been rebutted by the explanation given by him inasmuch as that explanation was both reasonable and probable. In order to appreciate the contention it is necessary to state certain facts.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: e it is established that the accused person has received a sum of money which was number due to him as a legal remuneration. Of companyrse, it is open

arguments.court_reasoning: Presumption under s.4(1) is mandatory presumption of law requiring proof to rebut, not mere reasonable and probable explanation; explanation must be proved true

arguments.claim: Use of word 'gratification' in s.4(1) requires proof of something more than mere receipt of money to raise presumption

anchor.surface_text: It was contended that the use of the word gratification in sub-s.  1  of s. 4 emphasises that the mere receipt of any money does not justify the raising of a presumption thereunder and that something more than the mere receipt of money has to be proved.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: to the Director General of Light Houses. Then he points out that it has number been established that though bills worth a lakh of rupees or so were al

arguments.court_reasoning: Rejected following C.I. Emden v. State of UP; proof of receipt of money other than legal remuneration sufficient to raise presumption

arguments.claim: Complainant nursed grievance against appellant due to faults found in work and requirement to demolish and redo

anchor.surface_text: According to him the complainant evidently nursed a grievance against the appellant because the latter used to find fault with his work that the complainant was required to demolish some construction and do the work over again.

arguments.claim: Complainant aggrieved by insistence on doing extra work of leveling ground and deepening well

anchor.surface_text: He further points out that the complainant also felt aggrieved because of the appellants insistence on the complainant doing the work of leveling the ground adjoining the staff quarters and deepening the temple well even though he would have been paid separately for this work.

arguments.claim: Complainant conceived idea of laying trap due to grievances

anchor.surface_text: It is because of these circumstances that according to Mr. Chari, the complainant conceived the idea of laying a trap for involving the appellant.

arguments.claim: No evidence apart from bare word of complainant that appellant demanded bribes

anchor.surface_text: He points out that apart from the bare statement of the complainant there is nothing to show that the appellant had been asking for any bribes.

arguments.claim: Suggestion to do work for temple was mere request, not using official position to coerce

anchor.surface_text: No doubt the appellant had suggested that some work for the temple should be done free by the complainant. But that was merely by way of request and nothing more and that there is nothing to show that he was using his official position to coerce the complainant for doing this work.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: th an appeal against an order of the Madras High Court setting aside the companyviction of an accused person under s. 161, I.P.C. In that case the acc

arguments.court_reasoning: High Court believed complainant's statement that appellant asked for bribe and rejected explanation

arguments.claim: Complainant not the kind of man who could be easily coerced

anchor.surface_text: He has taken us through considerable portions of the evidence on record to show that the complainant was not the kind of man who could be easily cowed down and it is unthinkable that the appellant would have tried to use pressure tactics

arguments.claim: No pressure used for obtaining bribe before passing previous bills worth lakh of rupees

anchor.surface_text: Then he points out that it has not been established that though bills worth a lakh of rupees or so were already passed for payment by the appellant, he had used any pressure for obtaining bribe.

arguments.claim: Unreasonable to hold appellant withheld ninth bill to force Rs.1000 bribe

anchor.surface_text: It would, therefore not be reasonable to hold that the appellant had withheld the ninth bill just for coercing the complainant to pay a thousand rupees to him by way of illegal gratification.

arguments.claim: Appellant applied for retirement on March 19, 1959, unlikely to demand small bribe of Rs.1000

anchor.surface_text: He then pointed out that actually on March 19, 1959, the appellant had applied to the Director General of Light Houses for permission to retire as from June 30, and requested him to settle his gratuity amount. In these circumstances ... would the appellant ... have been foolish enough to press him for a comparatively trivial amount of Rs. 1,000/- by way of bribe?

arguments.claim: Explanation that Rs.1000 was voluntarily paid for temple authorities is reasonable and probable

anchor.surface_text: He, therefore, urges that in the circumstances the explanation offered by the appellant which is to the effect that the complainant voluntarily paid to him a sum of Rs. 1,000/- on April 6, 1959, for being passed on to the temple authorities should be accepted as reasonable and probable.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: th an appeal against an order of the Madras High Court setting aside the companyviction of an accused person under s. 161, I.P.C. In that case the acc

arguments.court_reasoning: High Court rejected explanation believing complainant; no evidence appellant authorized to collect for temple; letter worthless

arguments.claim: Letter from D.S. Apte (Def Ex 32) received during visit, produced to police, conclusive against bribe

anchor.surface_text: According to Mr. Chari here, there is some material in addition to the explanation offered by the appellant which will go to rebut the Presumption raised under s. 4 (1) of the Act. He points out that there is the letter from D. S. Apte ... which the appellant claims to have received on or after March 13, 1959 ... this letter was produced by him immediately ... it is conclusive to disprove the money being received by way of bribe.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ompanystitute a branch of jurisprudence. These observations were made by this Court while dealing with an appeal against an order of the Madras High C

arguments.court_reasoning: High Court disbelieved Apte's evidence and held letter worthless

arguments.claim: Evidence of D.S. Apte supports explanation

anchor.surface_text: He also relies upon the evidence of D.S. Apte.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ervations were made by this Court while dealing wi

arguments.claim: High Court misstated law requiring more than reasonable true explanation to rebut; equates to prosecution burden

anchor.surface_text: His grievance is that the High Court has misstated and misapplied the law when it observed ... The usual standard of an explanation given by the accused which may reasonably be true ... cannot be enough ... Mr. Chari contends that upon the view taken by the High Court it would mean that an accused person is required to discharge more or less the same burden ... as the prosecution

court_response_anchor.surface_text: once arise under the section. It introduces an exception to the general rule as to the burden of proof in criminal cases and shifts the onus on to the

arguments.court_reasoning: High Court correct; s.4(1) 'shall presume' is presumption of law requiring disproof by proof, unlike discretionary presumption of fact

arguments.claim: Presumption rebutted by explanation reasonably true and consistent with innocence per Otto George Gfeller v. King

anchor.surface_text: He referred us to the decision in Otto George Gfeller v. The King and contended that whether a presumption arises from the common course of human affairs or from a statute there is no difference as to the manner in which that presumption could be rebutted.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ature has chosen to use the words shall presume and number may presume, the former a presumption of law and latter of fact. Both these phrases have be

arguments.court_reasoning: Gfeller case under presumption like s.114 Evidence Act (fact, discretionary); s.4(1) PCA is mandatory presumption of law

arguments.claim: Reduce sentence considering age and near retirement when prosecution started

anchor.surface_text: A plea was made before us that in view of the age of the appellant and the fact that he was just about to retire when the prosecution was started we should reduce the sentence to the period already undergone.

arguments.court_reasoning: Circumstances considered by Special Judge who gave minimal sentence of 1 year

arguments.claim: Presumption arises on proof of receipt of gratification other than legal remuneration; money receipt sufficient

anchor.surface_text: Dealing with it this Court has pointed out that what the prosecution has to prove is that the accused person has received gratification other than legal remuneration and that when it is shown that he has received a certain sum of money which was not a legal remuneration, then the condition prescribed by this section is satisfied.

arguments.claim: Requirements of s.4(1) fulfilled; presumption raised

anchor.surface_text: That being the legal position it must be held the requirements of sub-s. (1) of s. 4 have been fulfilled in the present case and the presumption thereunder must be raised.

arguments.claim: Accused must rebut by proof, not mere plausible explanation; explanation must be true

anchor.surface_text: The burden resting on the accused person in such a case would not be as light as it is where a presumption is raised under s. 114 of the Evidence Act and cannot be held to be discharged merely by reason of the fact that the explanation offered by the accused is reasonable and probable. It must further be shown that the explanation is a true one.

arguments.claim: s.4(1) presumption mandatory unlike discretionary under s.114 Evidence Act

anchor.surface_text: whereas under s. 114 of the Evidence Act it is open to the Court to draw or not to draw a presumption ... under sub-s. (1) of s. 4, however, if a certain fact is proved ... the court is required to draw a presumption

arguments.claim: 'Shall presume' is presumption of law, obligatory, defined in Evidence Act requiring disproof

anchor.surface_text: Shall presume has been defined in the Evidence Act as follows Whenever it is directed by this Act that the Court shall presume a fact, it shall regard such fact as proved unless and until it is disproved. It is a presumption of law and therefore it is obligatory on the court to raise this presumption

arguments.claim: Presumption rebutted only by proof establishing contrary so probable reasonable man acts on it

anchor.surface_text: A fact is said to be proved when its existence is directly established or when upon the material before it the Court finds its existence to be so probable that a reasonable man would act on the supposition that it exists. Unless, therefore, the explanation is supported by proof, the presumption created by the provision cannot be said to be rebutted.

arguments.claim: Following State of Madras v. A. Vaidyanatha Iyer: presumption shifts onus to accused requiring proof

anchor.surface_text: How the burden which has shifted to the accused under s. 4(1) of the prevention of Corruption Act is to be discharged has been considered by this Court in State of Madras v. A. Vaidyanatha Iyer where it has been observed Therefore, where it is proved that a gratification has been accepted, then the presumption shall at once arise under the section.

arguments.claim: High Court did not act unreasonably in rejecting explanation, letter, Apte's evidence

anchor.surface_text: The High Court disbelieved the evidence of Apte and held the letter to be worthless. In doing so it cannot be said that the High Court has acted unreasonably.

arguments.claim: No evidence appellant asked complainant for temple donation or authorized to collect

anchor.surface_text: No evidence was, however brought to our notice to show that the appellant had at any time asked the complainant to give any money by way of donation to the temple and indeed there is evidence to the contrary to the effect that none of the persons interested in the temple had authorised the appellant to collect any money

arguments.claim: Question of whether presumption rebutted is question of fact; SC slow to interfere with High Court

anchor.surface_text: Further the question whether a presumption of law or fact stands rebutted by the evidence or other material on record is one of fact and not law and this Court is slow to interfere with the view of facts taken by the High Court.

arguments.claim: High Court findings not based on erroneous view of presumption or manifestly erroneous assessment

anchor.surface_text: No doubt, it will be open to this Court to examine the evidence for itself where the High Court has proceeded upon an erroneous view as to the nature of the presumption or, again, where the assessment of facts made by the High Court is manifestly erroneous. The case before us does not suffer from either of these defects.

holdings.text: The requirements of sub-s. (1) of s. 4 of the Prevention of Corruption Act have been fulfilled in the present case and the presumption thereunder must be raised upon proof of receipt of gratification other than legal remuneration.

anchor.surface_text: Dealing with it this Court has pointed out that what the prosecution has to prove is that the accused person has received gratification other than legal remuneration and that when it is shown that he has received a certain sum of money which was not a legal remuneration, then the condition prescribed by this section is satisfied.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Prosecution proved receipt of Rs.1000 not legal remuneration; following C.I. Emden v. State of UP, mere money receipt satisfies condition for presumption despite 'gratification'; rejects need for additional proof.

holdings.text: Use of 'gratification' in s.4(1) does not require proof beyond mere receipt of money other than legal remuneration to raise presumption.

anchor.surface_text: It was contended that the use of the word gratification in sub-s.  1  of s. 4 emphasises that the mere receipt of any money does number justify the raising of a presumption thereunder and

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects petitioner's textual argument; applies precedent in C.I. Emden v. State of UP holding money receipt sufficient; consistent interpretation with valuable things clause.

holdings.text: Presumption under s.4(1) PCA is mandatory presumption of law ('shall presume') rebuttable only by proof establishing contrary as true, not merely by reasonable and probable explanation.

anchor.surface_text: The burden resting on the accused person in such a case would number be as light as it is where a presumption is raised under s. 114 of the Evidence Act and cannot be held to be discharged merely by reason of the fact that the explanation offered by the accused is reasonable and probable.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes discretionary 'may presume' under Evidence s.114 (fact) from obligatory 'shall presume' (law) defined in Evidence Act; follows State of Madras v. A. Vaidyanatha Iyer on shifted onus requiring proof.

holdings.text: Appellant's explanation that Rs.1000 was voluntarily paid for temple authorities has not rebutted the presumption as it is not proved true.

anchor.surface_text: It is because of these circumstances and because it believed the statement of the complainant that the appellant had asked him for a bribe that the High Court did number accept the appellants explanation that the money was paid by the complainant to him for being passed on to the temple trustee as true.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court believed complainant on demand, rejected Apte's evidence and letter as worthless; no proof appellant authorized to collect or asked complainant for donation; anthracene powder consistent with trap.

holdings.text: Whether presumption under s.4(1) stands rebutted is a question of fact; Supreme Court slow to interfere with High Court's view unless erroneous on law or manifestly wrong.

anchor.surface_text: Further the question whether a presumption of law or fact stands rebutted by the evidence or other material on record is one of fact and number law and this Court is slow to interfere with the view of facts taken by the High Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Standard appellate review; High Court applied correct law on presumption and factual assessment not perverse; no grounds for interference.

holdings.text: No reduction in sentence warranted given age and retirement proximity, as Special Judge already considered and imposed minimum one year RI.

anchor.surface_text: A plea was made before us that in view of the age of the appellant and the fact that he was just about to retire when the prosecution was started we should reduce the sentence to the period already undergone. These circumstances were borne in mind by the learned Special judge when he passed a substantive sentence of imprisonment of one year only though the maximum for the offence is seven years.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Mitigating factors already weighed by trial court imposing lenient sentence below maximum.

holdings.text: Appeal dismissed; convictions under s.161 IPC and s.5(1)(d) read with s.5(2) PCA and sentences affirmed.

anchor.surface_text: In the circumstances we dismiss the appeal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Presumption raised and not rebutted; factual findings upheld.

precedents.citation: C. 1. Emden v. State of Uttar Pradesh 1

anchor.surface_text: C. 1. Emden v. State of Uttar Pradesh 1 . Dealing with it this Court has pointed out that what the prosecution has to prove is that the accused person has received gratification other than legal remuneration and that when it is shown that he has received a certain sum of money which was number a legal remuneration, then the companydition prescribed by this section is satisfied. This Court then proceeded to observe If the word gratification is companystrued to mean money paid by way of a bribe then it would be futile or superfluous to prescribe for the raising of the presumption. Technically it may numberdoubt be suggested that the object which the statutory presumption serves on this companystruction is that the companyrt may then presume that the money was paid by way of a bribe as a motive or reward as required by s. 161 of the Code. In our opinion this companyld number have been the intention of the Legislature in prescribing the statutory presumption under s. 4 1 .

precedents.case_name: C.I. Emden v. State of Uttar Pradesh
precedents.cited_proposition: mere receipt of money other than legal remuneration satisfies condition for presumption under s.4(1) of Prevention of Corruption Act; gratification does not require proof of being bribe
precedents.cited_holding: If the word gratification is companystrued to mean money paid by way of a bribe then it would be futile or superfluous to prescribe for the raising of the presumption.

precedents.citation: Otto George Gfeller v. The King 1

anchor.surface_text: Otto George Gfeller v. The King 1  and companytended that whether a presumption arises from the companymon companyrse of human affairs or from a statute there is numberdifference as to the manner in which that presumption companyld be rebutted. In the decision referred to above the Privy Council, when dealing with a case from Nigeria, held that if an explanation was given which the jury think might reasonably be true and which is companysistent with innocence, although they were number companyvinced of its truth, the accused person would be A. 1. R.  1943  P. C. 211. entitled to acquittal inasmuch as the prosecution would have failed to discharge the duty cast upon it of satisfying the jury beyond reasonable doubt of the guilt of the accused.

precedents.case_name: Otto George Gfeller v. The King
precedents.cited_proposition: reasonable and probable explanation consistent with innocence rebuts presumption even if not fully convincing
precedents.cited_holding: if an explanation was given which the jury think might reasonably be true and which is companysistent with innocence, although they were number companyvinced of its truth, the accused person would be entitled to acquittal

precedents.citation: State of Madras v. A. Vaidyanatha Iyer 1

anchor.surface_text: State of Madras v. A. Vaidyanatha Iyer 1  where it has been observed Therefore, where it is proved that a gratification has been accepted, then the presumption shall at once arise under the section. It introduces an exception to the general rule as to the burden of proof in criminal cases and shifts the onus on to the accused. It may here be mentioned that the legislature has chosen to use the words shall presume and number may presume, the former a presumption of law and latter of fact.

precedents.case_name: State of Madras v. A. Vaidyanatha Iyer
precedents.cited_proposition: presumption under s.4(1) PCA is mandatory presumption of law requiring proof to rebut, not mere plausible explanation
precedents.cited_holding: Shall presume has been defined in the Evidence Act as follows Whenever it is directed by this Act that the Court shall presume a fact, it shall regard such fact as proved unless and until it is disproved. It is a presumption of law and therefore it is obligatory on the companyrt to raise this presumption
